Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story:
I stared at the calendar, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in on me. My family’s annual holiday gathering was this weekend, a tradition that meant everything to my parents. They expected me to be there, to help cook, laugh, and share stories—just like every year. My mother had already called twice, reminding me how important it was to uphold our family values, especially now that my younger cousins looked up to me.

But on the same weekend, my pharmacy was hosting a crucial workshop on the latest prescription guidelines. Missing it would mean falling behind on important updates, risking my ability to counsel patients properly. My supervisor had emphasized how essential it was for all pharmacists to attend, and I knew my colleagues would be there, ready to discuss what they’d learned.

As I sat at my desk, the invitation to the workshop open on my laptop and my mother’s voice echoing in my mind, I felt torn. The pressure to honor my family’s expectations clashed painfully with my professional responsibility. My heart pounded as I tried to imagine disappointing either side, feeling the impossible pull of both roles.
